Cell culture and co-transfection
Timing: 5–7 days
HEK293 TREx™ cells expressing TetR are initially cultured in a tetracycline-free growth medium. The cells are seeded at a density to yield a ∼70% confluent cell culture on the day of transfection. This protocol is also compatible with other cell lines expressing TetR.
Culture TRExTM-293 cells in complete medium consisting of 10 mL of DMEM supplemented with 10% (v/v) tetracycline-free FBS and 1× penicillin-streptomycin (at final concentration of 1 unit/mL of penicillin, 0.1 mg/mL streptomycin) 37°C and 5% CO2 in 100 mm tissue culture plates.
Passage the cells when they reach 80%–90% confluency by removing the culture medium and washing the cells once with pre-warmed (37°C) 1× PBS.
Aspirate the PBS and add 1 mL of 0.025% (w/v) 1× trypsin-EDTA at 37°C.
Wait for 1 min to allow for cellular dissociation from the cell culture plate.
Add 9 mL of pre-warmed (37°C) complete medium to stop the reaction.
Pipette well to suspend the cells and transfer 2 mL of the cell suspension to a new 100 mm tissue culture plate containing 8 mL of fresh pre-warmed complete medium.
Note: Passage cells every 2–3 days at a splitting ratio of 1:5 − 1:10 to prevent fully confluent cultures and maintain cell viability.
If cells are ready to be set up for transfection, then count the cells and seed according to experiment. 60 mm plates are used below for the DNA-RNA immunoprecipitation (DRIP) as more cells are required for this assay.
Take a 20 μL aliquot of the cell suspension and mix it 1:1 with Trypan blue before counting cells using a hemocytometer.

To have cells at ∼70% confluence in a 60 mm plate, seed 2.0 ×106 cells per 60 mm tissue culture plate containing pre-warmed and fresh complete medium. Place the plates at 37°C and 5% CO2 for next day transfection.
On the day of transfection, prepare Tet+ complete medium by adding 10 μL of the 1 mg/mL tetracycline stock solution to 10 mL of pre-warmed complete medium in a 50 mL conical tube (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).

DNA-RNA immunoprecipitation (DRIP) to measure LasR-based R-loop modulation
Timing: 4–5 days

We describe a DNA-RNA immunoprecipitation (DRIP) protocol (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]) that uses both commercially available and reagents generated in-house. Specifically, we use an anti-RNA-DNA hybrid (S9.6) antibody purified in-house from mouse hybridoma cells (ATCC, HB-8730). In this protocol, we digest genomic DNA with a cocktail of restriction enzymes and confirm digestion using agarose gel electrophoresis. The input DNA and DNA from IPs are purified using a commercially available Gel/PCR DNA Fragment Extraction Kit and used in qPCR. If assessing R-loop modulation in trans, as in the case of the rDNA shown in this protocol, include qPCR primers for both the targeted locus (i.e., IGS28) and the R-loop-containing locus modulated in trans (i.e., IGS18) (Abraham et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]). If assessing R-loop modulation in cis, as in the case of the β-ACTIN locus shown elsewhere (Khosraviani et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11]), include the qPCR primers that generate PCR amplicons that are within the vicinity of the sgRNA sites as summarized further below.

Figure 5. Overview of DNA-RNA immunoprecipitation (DRIP) using the S9.6 antibody
Co-transfected cells are first lysed, and the proteins are digested (steps 14–18). Genomic DNA (gDNA) is isolated (steps 19–31) followed by a 15–18 h digestion with restriction enzymes (steps 32–48) to obtain DNA fragments of 200–500 bp. The digested DNA is incubated for 15–18 h with the S9.6 antibody (Ab) that detects the RNA-DNA hybrid moiety of R-loops (steps 49–53). The immunocomplexes are precipitated and washed, DNA fragments are purified, and qPCR is run to measure RNA-DNA signals (steps 54–67).
Cell culture and RED/dRED induction conditions can be performed as presented herein previously. Remove the cell culture medium and wash cells twice with 5 mL of ice-cold 1× PBS.
Critical: Wash three times if the culture medium contains toxic drugs. Dispose of the toxic liquid waste according to the biosafety guidelines.

Add 5 mL 1× PBS to each plate. Gently scrape the cells into a 15 mL conical tube.
Pellet the cells gently by centrifuging at 270 × g for 5 min at 21°C–25°C.
Resuspend the cells in 1.6 mL of TE.
Add 41.5 μL of 20% SDS and 5 μL of 20 mg/mL proteinase K. To resuspend the cells, gently pipette up and down with a 1,000 μL micropipette tip, which one can cut to widen the tip orifice and minimize cellular stress during pipetting.
Incubate with constant rotation for 15–18 h at 37°C.
Add 1.6-mL of phenol-chloroform to each tube.
Critical: Perform this step under the fume hood and wear PPE.
Gently invert to mix the tube, then centrifuge it at 450 × g for 5 min at 21°C–25°C.
Use a widened 1,000 μL micropipette tip (as in step 129) to carefully transfer the top aqueous layer (∼1.5 mL) to a new conical tube.
Add 1.4 mL of phenol-chloroform and repeat major steps 20 and 21.
While samples are being centrifuged, add 80 μL of 3 M NaOAc pH 5.2 and 1,920 μL of 100% EtOH to a new 15 mL conical tube.
Transfer 800 μL of the aqueous phase from step 22 to the tube from step 23.
Gently mix by inverting the tube until a ‘whitish’ fiber-like precipitate appears.
Critical: Do not centrifuge to pellet the DNA as this can promote RNA contamination and interfere with immunoprecipitation.
Spool the DNA fiber with a 100 μL micropipette tip and transfer the DNA fiber into a 1.5 mL tube.
Wash the DNA fiber five times each with 1,000 μL of 70% EtOH and gentle inverting of the tube to allow the fibers to settle.

Critical: Do not centrifuge to pellet the DNA as this can promote RNA contamination and interfere with immunoprecipitation.
After the final wash, carefully remove as much of the EtOH as possible.
Dry the genomic DNA (gDNA) pellets for 2–3 h at 21°C–25°C.
Carefully add 200 μL of TE to each tube.
Using a cut 200 μL micropipette tip, very gently resuspend the gDNA pellet.
Critical: The mixture will be viscous, and the DNA fibers will be visible. Do not pipette excessively or vortex.

Figure 6. Representative results related to DRIP experiments employing the LasR system
(A) Representative agarose gel electrophoresis illustrating typical chromatin fragments obtained following the digestion of DNA with restriction enzymes in preparation for chromatin pulldown experiments.
(B and C) DRIP analysis shows that using RED (B) or dRED (C) together with sgIGS28 respectively decreased and increased R-loop levels in trans at the spatially proximal IGS18 site. RED results in (B) are shown before (left, %Input) and after (right, %Input/IgG) normalization to IgG signals to control for background variability especially within highly repetitive DNA loci.

(D and E) DRIP analysis shows that using RED (D) or dRED (E) together with sgIGS28 does not alter the levels of R-loops at unrelated genetic loci.
(F) Schematic summarizing the pools of sgRNAs tested so far with this LasR system protocol when applied in trans at rDNA as shown previously (Abraham et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]) and herein or used in cis at the 5′Pause site of the single-copy β-ACTIN locus as shown elsewhere (Khosraviani et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11]). Testing different pools of sgRNAs targeting both DNA strands allowed for the combination of three sgRNAs that specifically target to the locus of interest and enriched the RED and dRED chimaeras in ChIP at the targeted loci. (A–F) HEK293T cells were used; data are shown as mean ± S.D.; two-tailed t-test (A–C) or two-tailed ANOVA with Tuckey’s multiple comparisons test (D and E); N = 3 biologically independent experiments.
Add 40 μL of 3 M NaOAc pH 5.2 to the digested DNA.
Add 400 μL of phenol-chloroform and mix well.

Centrifuge at 16,100 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Transfer 300 μL of the top aqueous phase to a new tube.
Repeat steps 37–39.
Add 2.4 volumes (∼600 μL) of cold 100% EtOH.
Precipitate DNA by incubating for 15 min at −20°C.
Centrifuge at 16,100 × g for 30 min at 4°C to pellet the DNA.
Remove the supernatant and add 1 mL of cold 70% EtOH.
Centrifuge at 16,100 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Air dry for 30 min under the fume hood.
Resuspend the pellet in 50 μL of TE.
Measure the concentration (OD260) of the DNA using NanoDrop2000 or similar method. The concentration should be ∼400–1,000 ng/μL (see troubleshooting #5[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).

Add 4.4 μg of digested DNA for each IP in a new 1.5 mL low retention tube and top-up to a total of 100 μL with nuclease-free ddH2O.
Note: As an anti-RNA-DNA hybrid specificity control, treatment with recombinant RNase H1 in vitro can be performed by incubating 4.4 μg of digested DNA with 20 μL (100 U) of RNase H1, 10 μL of 10× RNase H1 buffer (supplied with recombinant RNase H1), and topping up to 100 μL with nuclease-free water. Samples can then be incubated for 15–18 h at 37°C before proceeding with the immunoprecipitation (Abraham et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]).
Note: Perform two independent IPs for each sample by using the S9.6 antibody to pull down DNA-RNA hybrids or anti-IgG as mock pulldown control.
Add 350 μL of TE buffer and 50 μL of 10× binding buffer to each sample.
Set aside 50 μL of each sample to serve as input.
Note: Note that this is 10% of input, and this information will be used to quantify enrichments as percent input.
Add 10 μg of the S9.6 antibody to each IP tube. For the mock IP controls, add 10 μg of the mouse anti-IgG antibody instead.
Rotate for 15–18 h at 4°C.
Per each IP sample, wash 50 μL of Dynabeads or similar three times with 1 mL of the 1× binding buffer by rotating for 10 min at 21°C–25°C for each wash in a new set of tubes. Pellet the beads on the DynaMagTM-2 Magnet rack or centrifuge if applicable/preferred, and remove the 1× binding buffer.
Note: Using less than 50 μL of Dynabeads can significantly lower the percent input.
Add the antibody-DNA mix from step 52 directly into the tubes prepared in step 54.
Rotate for 2 h at 4°C.
Pellet the beads and discard the supernatant.

Wash the beads three times with 1 mL of the 1× binding buffer by rotating for 10 min at 21°C–25°C.
Resuspend the beads in 250 μL of DRIP elution buffer.
Add 200 μL of DRIP elution buffer to each input (from step 51).
Add 7 μL of proteinase K to a final concentration of 0.5 mg/mL to each sample and mix well.
Incubate for 45 min at 55°C.
Pellet the beads in the IP samples and transfer the eluate to a new low retention tube.
Purify the DNA samples using Geneaid Gel/PCR DNA fragment extraction kit according to the manufacturer’s protocol here[href=https://www.geneaid.com/data/files/1605861013102532959.pdf], with the exception to elute the samples with 250 μL.
Run quantitative real-time PCR (qRT-PCR) using SensiFast No-ROX SYBR according to manufacturer’s protocol here[href=https://www.froggabio.com/media/bioline_brochures/sensifast_sybr_no_rox_kit_protocol.pdf] (see troubleshooting #6–7[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]). The primers used here are listed in Table S2[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2042-Mmc1.pdf].
Perform the following to calculate the %Input/IgG for each sample:
Adjusted Input (%Input) = Log (Your dilution factor, 2).
Corrected Ct = 100 × 2ˆ(Adjusted Input – Ct IP).
Data can be presented relative to the negative background control (IgG):
%Input/IgG = corrected Ct for IP/Corrected Ct for IgG.
